Sulphated Al-MCM-41: A simple, efficient and recyclable catalyst for synthesis of substituted aryl ketones/olefins via alcohols addition to alkynes and coupling with styrenes Kishor V. Wagh a Aravind L. Gajengi a Dharitri Rath c K.M. Parida b ⁎ Bhalchandra M. Bhanage a ⁎ a Department of Chemistry, Institute of Chemical Technology, Matunga, Mumbai, 400 019, India Department of Chemistry Institute of Chemical Technology Matunga Mumbai 400 019 India b Department of Chemistry, Centre for Nano Science and Nano Technology, Institute of Technical Education & Research, Siksha‘O’ Anusandhan University, Khandagiri, Bhubaneswar, 751 030, India Department of Chemistry Centre for Nano Science and Nano Technology Institute of Technical Education & Research Siksha‘O’ Anusandhan University Khandagiri Bhubaneswar 751 030 India c Rajdhani College, Bhubaneswar, Odisha, 751003, India Rajdhani College Bhubaneswar Odisha 751003 India ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract A series of sulphate modified Al-MCM-41 acid catalysts are synthesized following impregnation and co-condensation methods The physico-chemical characterizations of all the samples are done by XRD, FT-IR, TGA/DTA, TPD, N2 adsorption and desorption study, SEM, HRTEM and EDAX etc. The structural advantages of Al-MCM-41 such as large specific surface area, wide pore size and pore volume and Bronsted and Lewis acid sites favor the coupling reaction. The catalysts endorsed the direct addition of alcohols to alkynes as well as their coupling with styrenes. The various combinations of alcohols with alkynes and styrenes are compatible with diverse functional groups to synthesize a substituted aryl ketones, as well as olefins with good to excellent yields. Additionally, the approach is advantageous in terms using alcohols, discounting the pre-functionalization and generation of waste by-products. Used precursors, alkynes and styrenes, are valuable since they are stable and found in many biologically active compounds. This current research work provides supplements to CC bond formation methodologies as a single step with atom economy and recyclable approach under mild and environmentally benign conditions. Keywords Sulphated Al-MCM-41 CC bond formation Heterogeneous catalysis Atom economy Sustainable chemistry 1 Introduction Cross-coupling reactions play a crucial role in the construction of pharmaceuticals, naturally occurring compounds, agrochemicals and other practically useful molecules [1–7]. Specially, CC bond formation reactions are attractive and have central importance in modern organic synthesis [8–12]. Classical literature processes for construction of CC bond involve reactions between pre-functionalized hydrocarbons using stoichiometric amounts of reagents [13–16]. These methodologies have shown huge potential, but they suffer from some disadvantages like requirement of extra synthetic steps, inert conditions and generation of quantitative amounts of salts as by-products. To address this issue, search for atom-economic and environmentally benign methods for CC bond formation is of crucial importance in synthetic chemistry. In this regards, direct dehydrative coupling of alcohols with various nucleophiles has received a lot of interest [17]. It is considered as a clean route because alcohols form a highly atom-efficient alternative which are abundantly available, economical as well as environmentally benign [18]. Therefore, linkage of COH bond with a CH bond definitely bears an advantage to form a CC bond as it produces water as the only by-product. Thus alcohols are used as alkylating agents for dehydrative type Friedel-Crafts reactions using transition-metals and various acids as catalysts [19–21]. Direct use of alcohols in cross-coupling with alkynes or olefins is rarely studied despite a great potential lying in the fact that alkynes and olefins are valuable synthon in organic chemistry [22–26]. Dehydrative coupling for formation of CC bond was reported for the first time by Jiao and co-workers in 2009 [27]. The authors utilized Fe(OTf)3 as a catalyst for dehydrative coupling of benzylic alcohols with terminal alkynes in the presence of trifluoromethanesulfonic acid (TfOH). Fortunately further studies of the reaction reveal that besides the coupling of alkynes with alcohols, the CC bond does not remain unsaturated in the final product [28–31]. It gets transformed into selective ketone functionalities. This is of vast interest in terms of atom economy as it reduces down the number of steps to reach products of interest. Recently some research groups including ours have made a remarkable progress in this regards. Binary catalytic systems, such as Amberlyst-15/[Bmim][PF6] [28], Ca(NTf2)/NH4PF6 [29], FeCl3·6H2O in MeNO2 [30] and FeCl3/AgSbF6 catalyst in DCE [31] have been used for such transformations. Acknowledging the significance of olefin derivatives in biologically active molecules and natural products, Yamamoto and co-workers developed a dehydrative coupling scheme of benzylic alcohols with styrenes catalyzed by Pd(II) using (CF3CO)2O as additive [32]. Advancements in such type of coupling reactions has been explored by us as well as other research groups using various catalytic systems, such as Bronsted acidic ionic liquids [33], NaHSO4/SiO2 [34], Fe [35], TfOH [36], H6P2W18O62 [37]. However, most of the methodologies explored to date for dehydrative coupling have some limitations such as utilization of expensive, moisture sensitive and corrosive reagents, high catalyst loadings, long reaction times, use of high temperatures, low yield of products etc. Thus development of an efficient and convenient method, to avoid of the above shortcomings, for dehydrative CC coupling reaction will be a precious impetus to this field. Catalysis using solid acids has been emerging as an incomparable alternative to liquid acid catalysis for fine chemical synthesis in acid-catalyzed reactions [38–42]. Solid acids are easily separable from reaction medium [42]. Apart from this these are also non-toxic, non-corrosive, easily recyclable and reusable [42]. Solid acids such as ion-exchange resins [43], SO3H-functionalized porous carbons [44,45] and zeolites [42] are porous in nature. Active acidic sites of such catalysts are principally situated inside the pores of the material [38–45]. Consequently, the performance of acid catalyzed reactions depends upon mass transfer to and from in the pores [38–45]. Herein, we demonstrate a facile synthesis of sulfated Al-MCM-41 prepared by sol-gel procedure possessing much superior catalytic assets (activity and recyclability) for direct addition of alcohols to alkynes as well as direct coupling with styrenes (Scheme 1 ). 2 Experimental 2.1 Chemicals and reagents All chemicals and reagents of A. R. grade were purchased from SD Fine Chemicals Ltd., Mumbai, India and used without further purification. 2.2 Preparation of sulphated Al-MCM-41 catalyst Al-MCM-41 was synthesized by sol-gel process carried out at room temperature [46]. The silica and aluminum sources (tetraethyl orthosilicate = 22.2 mL and aluminum isopropoxide = 2.04 gm) were first mixed under stirring (solution A). The amount of aluminum source was taken in such a way that the starting Si/Al ratio is 10. At the same time, 4.8 gm of hexadecyl trimethylammonium chloride (CTACl), used as surfactant, was dissolved in 20 mL of 11.2 N of aq. HCl under stirring (solution B). Then solution A was added to solution B and the mixture was gently stirred at room temperature for 75 min (CTACl/TEOS = 0.3). The condensation reaction was promoted by dropwise addition of 2 wt.% aq. NH3 until the pH of the mixture reached 4. The resultant solution was kept under stirring for an additional 1 h. The solid material so obtained was recovered by filtration, washed with deionized water, dried at 110 °C overnight, and finally calcined in static air at 550 °C for 12 h (Scheme 2 ). In 1 g of Al-MCM-41 was treated with required amount of 0.01 M H2SO4 (amount varies from 11 to 55 mL) for 2 h at room temperature and heated at 70 °C till complete dryness. The sample was then kept in an oven at 110 °C for 10 h followed by calcination at 550 °C in a muffle furnace (Scheme 2). Further the materials are designated as S/Al-MCM-41-x (x = wt% of sulphate). 2.3 Synthesis mechanism The sulphate modified Al-MCM-41 materials are synthesized following sol-gel and impregnation methods. By incorporating Al3+ into the silica framework of MCM-41, a partial charge deficiency is generated. It leads to the development of Lewis acid sites. Again the sulphate group is impregnated into the Al-MCM-41 framework, which is co-ordinated to the Si-OH and Al-OH groups. Hence strong Bronsted acid sites may be developed in the materials which are required for coupling reactions for alkyne and alcohols. All the acid site data are further confirmed from NH3-TPD and pyridine FTIR study. 2.4 Physico-chemical characterisation of sulphated Al-MCM-41 catalyst 2.4.1 XRD The crystallinity and orderness of porous materials are determined by XRD patterns. The low angle and wide angle (inserted) XRD of Al-MCM-41 and the sulphate modified samples are shown in Fig. 1 . A strong diffraction peak (d100) at 2θ = 2.0° along with two slightly broad peaks (d110, d200) is observed for Al-MCM-41. These are due to long range ordered mesoporousity and intra-particle porous systems. In comparison to the parent Al-MCM-41, the modified samples show slight shift in peak values and reduction in intensities. Still the mesoporous structure of the materials remains intact [47]. In case of the wide angle data all the samples exhibit a broad peak at around 2θ = 23° due to amorphous silica in MCM-41. 2.4.2 N2 adsorption-desorption study Before analysis of BET specific surface area all the samples were pretreated under N2 atmosphere at 200 °C for 2 h and then analysed. The specific surface area of all the materials is calculated by BET method (Table 1 ). The parent Al-MCM-41 shows a surface area of 1089 m2/g. The 30% and 40% sulphate loaded Al-MCM-41 show the BET surface area as 780 and 633 m2/g respectively. While impregnating the sulphate groups they are loaded on the surface and pore mouths of the parent material. That’s why the surface area decreased after sulphate modification. But for 40% sulphate loading the surface area as well as pore volume (0.4490 cm3/g) and pore width (28.1 Å) are maximum compared to other sulphate modified samples. This may be due to the increase in inter porosity in the parent Al-MCM-41 material. Again some extra framework of SO4 2−-Al-O-Si may be introduced in the parent Al-MCM-41. Though the surface area of modified materials is less compared to the parent Al-MCM-41, the active sites are uniformly distributed over the support to provide excellent activity towards the coupling reaction. Hence 40% sulphate loaded Al-MCM-41 is found to be the best material in view of the surface area, pore size as well as pore volume for the desired coupling reaction. 2.4.3 FTIR analysis The stretching and bending vibration of different functional groups can be studied by FTIR study. The FTIR spectra of Al-MCM-41 and all the sulphate modified samples are given in Fig. S1 (See ESI). The broad band at 3000–3600 cm−1 is attributed to HOH stretching vibration due to presence of absorbed water molecules. The HOH bending vibration appeared at around 1635 cm−1 indicating the presence of aqueous molecules in all the samples. The sharp peaks at 1020–1120 cm−1 is mainly for SiO stretching vibration in SiOSi structure of silica framework. Again the SO stretching band in sulphate group appeared at 1100 cm−1 which is merged with the SiO band. The peak at 957 cm−1 in Al-MCM-41 confirmed the bonding of SiOAl. There is a blue shift (towards higher wave number) in the peak for sulphate loaded samples confirming the bonding of SO4 −2 with SiOAl framework. The peak around 800 cm−1 corresponds to SiOSi symmetric stretching vibrations in MCM-41 framework. The peak at 555 cm−1 is due to stretching vibrations of HSO4 − .[48] 2.4.4 NH3-TPD analysis The total acid sites can be measured by NH3 TPD analysis. The TPD for Al-MCM-41 and the sulphate modified samples are shown in figure (S2–S7) (See ESI). The total amount of NH3 adsorbed corresponds to the total acid sites present in the material. From the figures it is clear that the total acid sites are increasing with increase in sulphate loading. In case of Al-MCM-41 the amount of NH3 adsorbed is 2788 μmol/gm with a single peak at 140 °C. But in case of sulphate modified Al-MCM-41 materials there are multiple peaks. The 40% sulphate modified Al-MCM-41 sample shows peaks at 140 °C, 230 °C and 550 °C and adsorbed maximum 4503.9 μmol/gm of NH3. By increasing the sulphate loading further to 50 wt% there is slight decrease in acid sites. This may be due to multiple layer of dispersion of sulphate over the Al-MCM-41 support. So 40% sulphated Al-MCM-41 is the optimized material for target acid catalyzed reactions. 2.4.5 TG-DTA analysis The thermal decomposition of materials can be studied by thermo gravimetric analysis. The TG-DTA data of Al-MCM-41 and sulphate modified Al-MCM-41 are given in figure (S8–S13) (See ESI). In the figures all the samples show decomposition in two steps. There is one sharp peak at 110 °C, which is due to removal of physically absorbed water molecules in the voids formed by crystal agglomeration in the mesopores. The second weight loss is due to decomposition and removal of occluded organics. The complete removal of all the organic surfactants is done around 800 °C. For Al-MCM-41 sample the total wt. loss is 15%. It increases to a maximum value of 35% in case of sulphate modified samples. The DTA curves complement the TGA data in a well manner. The first endothermic peak is due to removal of absorbed water molecules. The decomposition of sulphate groups to SO2 is also associated with the endothermic peak. Above 200 °C there is rise in DTA curve upto 800 °C.[49] 2.4.6 SEM analysis The surface morphology and particle shape and size are confirmed from the SEM study. The SEM figures of Al-MCM-41 and 40 wt% of sulphate modified Al-MCM-41 are shown in Fig. 2 . Formation of spherical particles is clearly indicated in both the cases. In Al-MCM-41 some particles are completely grown and some are in the process. Some particles agglomerate to form larger particles. The average particle size is 1–1.5 μm. In 40% sulphated Al-MCM-41 all the particles are completely grown with a variety of size. The particle size ranges from 0.4 to 2 μm. The elemental dispersive spectrum (EDS) of 40 wt% sulphated Al-MCM-41 shows the presence of only Si, S, Al and O elements. 2.4.7 Pyridine adsorption FTIR study A pyridine adsorption study by FTIR is a reliable method for measurement of acid sites present in the materials [50,51]. All the sulphate modified Al-MCM-41 samples were analysed by pyridine adsorption through FTIR and the data were shown in figure (S14–S15) (See ESI). The hydroxyl groups reside in the ranges 3400–3800 cm−1. The peak at around 3740 cm−1 is due to Si-OH groups for parent MCM-41. The Al-OH groups correspond to the peaks around 3680–3670 cm−1. Again the vibrations peaks at 3645–3630 cm−1 correspond to the hydroxyl groups present in the super cage of the silica framework [52]. The lower region vibrational frequencies at 1650–1400 cm−1 are due to pyridine ring vibration that adsorbed on various acid sites of the material. Two types of adsorbed pyridine species were observed. The bands at 1630 and 1530 cm−1 are due to Bronsted acid sites for sulphate modification. These peaks are absent in the parent Al-MCM-41 samples and present in all other sulphate modified samples. Hence indicates the increase in Bronsted acid sites due to sulphate modification. But the frequency bands, at 1430, 1570 and 1610 cm−1 correspond to the Lewis acid sites due to pyridine bonded to co-ordinatively unsaturated Al+3 in the silica framework, are present in all the materials. Again the band at 1470 cm−1 originated from the co-adsoption of pyridine on both B/L acid sites. The concentrations of B/L acid sites and B/L ratio can be calculated from the peak area of the corresponding bands. With increase in sulphate loading the peak area as well as the B/L ratio increased proportionately (Table 2 ). Therefore the pyridine FTIR data well complements to the catalytic activity of the synthesized materials. 3 Results and discussion The investigations are started by selecting reaction of phenylacetylene (1a) with benzhydrol (2a) as a model reaction to optimize reaction conditions. We systematically examined the influences of a series of sulphated Al-MCM-41 catalysts and various other acid catalysts by observing effects of various solvents, catalyst loading, substrate ratio, time and temperature on model reaction. As shown in Table 3 , six sulphated Al-MCM-41 catalysts with different sulphate loadings such as Al-MCM-41, S/Al-MCM-41-10, S/Al-MCM-41-20, S/Al-MCM-41-30, S/Al-MCM-41-40 and S/Al-MCM-41-50 were tested (Table 3, entries 1–6). It should be noted that, when S/Al-MCM-41-40 was used as the catalyst, 42% of the desired product 3aa was obtained (Table 3, entry 5). It was seen that the other catalysts in the series were not able to convert 1a and 2a in to 3aa completely under the standard conditions. The reason for this can be the acid sites of the catalysts are not sufficient for this transformation as it is an acid catalyzed reaction. Some other commonly employed solid acid catalysts were also tested such as Montmorillonite K-10, Amberlyst 15, and H3PW12O40 for the model reaction. It was observed that these furnish lower yields as compared to S/Al-MCM-41-40 (Table 3, entries 7–9). These results indicate that the catalyst, has a significant influence on the progress of the reaction. This activity can be credited to the acid sites created due to sulphate loading on Al-MCM-41. The sulphate groups are uniformly distributed on the large surface of the parent Al-MCM-41. Surface area of the catalysts play a major role for their activity. In addition to the large BET surface area the materials also show tunable pore diameter, high porosity and a narrow pore size distribution. Among the sulphate loaded samples S/Al-MCM-41-40 shows the highest surface area as well as pore size and pore volume. The pore size is compatible to the organic substrates. Hence the catalytic activity results are in accordance with the surface characterization data. Various organic solvents are tested for the model reaction using S/Al-MCM-41-40 catalyst. It was observed that DCE is superior to other solvents (Table 3, entries 10–14). To improve the yield of 3aa, loading of catalyst was studied and it was observed that 50 mg catalyst loading is essential to bring about the desired transformation of 3aa (Table 3, entries 15–16). Study of catalyst loading points out that the acidic concentration of catalyst is essential for the reaction. Furthermore, it is attempted to optimize the ratio of the substrate 1a to 2a and 1:1.2 ratio was found to be most favorable for this transformation (Table 3, entry 17). The yield of 3aa decreased unfortunately when increasing the mole ratio of 2a with 1a. (Table 3, entry 18). It was reasonable that the moles of 2a increase with 1a, the formation water more due to dehydrative self etherification of 2a which resulted in the formation ketone from 1a, therefore leading to decrease in yield of 3aa. Influence of time on reaction progress was also explored, and it was found that a minimum of 8 h were required to obtain the highest yield of 3aa (Table 3, entries 19–20). Subsequently we tried to search for perfect reaction temperature. Significant and maximum yield of 3aa was obtained at 70 °C (Table 3, entries 21–22). A control experiment was also carried out in the absence of solvent and catalyst which did not result into any desired product 3aa (Table 3, entries 23–24). From these optimization studies, the optimal conditions for 3aa synthesis were documented to be: 1a (1 mmol), 2a (1.2 mmol), S/Al-MCM-41-40 (50 mg), in DCE (2 mL) at 70 °C for 8 h. From these optimization studies, the optimal conditions for 3aa synthesis were documented to be: 1a (1 mmol), 2a (1.2 mmol), S/Al-MCM-41-40 (50 mg), in DCE (2 mL) at 70 °C for 8 h. With the optimized conditions at hand we tried to explore the scope of the reaction for synthesis of substituted ketones (Table 4 ). First, when 1a was reacted with 2a, the corresponding product (3aa) was obtained in 87% yield (Table 4, entry 1). For 2a bearing p-OCH3 and p-Cl groups the reactions proceed smoothly to furnish the desired products (3ab, 3ac) in 85% and 86% yields, respectively (Table 4, entries 2–3). Notably, benzhydrol with a sterically hindered methyl group at ortho position also facilitates a satisfying yield of (3ad) in 81% (Table 4, entry 4). Comparable results were obtained when 1-phenylethanol and their analogues with a variety of substituents (-CH3, −OCH3, −Cl and −Br) were made to react with 1a. The reactions give corresponding products (3ae-3ai) in moderate to good yields (Table 4, entries 5–9). Afterwards, various analogues of phenylacetylenes were also studied for their reactions with 2a, and it was observed that substrates having (-Me, −OMe, −Cl) are suitable for this protocol leading to the particular products (3ba-3ea) in good to excellent yields (Table 4, entries 10–12). To our delight, aliphatic alkyne subjected to the optimized conditions, affords the corresponding product (3fa) in moderate yield (Table 4, entry 13). The scope and generality of the methodology was extended to the synthesis of substituted olefins under similar reaction conditions and the results are summarized (Table 5 ). While 3a could react with 2a in the presence of sulphated Al-MCM-41 under the optimized reaction conditions to deliver the preferred product (4aa) in excellent yield (Table 5, entry 1). Styrenes bearing electron donating groups or halo substituents on the phenyl ring also reacted well with 2a to furnish desired compounds (4ba-4fa) in excellent yields (Table 5, entries 2–6). The reaction yield had no significant differences when 2a with substituents (-OCH3, −CH3, −Cl) and 1-phenylethanol were reacted with 3a to furnish the particular products (4ab-4ae) (Table 5, entries 7–10). 4 Recycle study In the case of solid acid catalysts, the most crucial point is their catalytic stability and recyclability. Therefore we investigated the recyclability of the developed catalyst sulphated Al-MCM-41 for a model reaction (synthesis of 3aa). To check the stability and activity of sulphated Al-MCM-41, a series of six repeated runs for the synthesis 3aa were carried out and the results are summarized in Fig. 3 . The results clearly indicate that sulphated Al-MCM-41 is a stable, active and recyclable catalyst. The decrease in yield from fresh to sixth recycle is might be due to decrease in acidic strength of catalyst. 5 Plausible reaction pathway On the basis of experimental observations and literature information[11,14,17] a plausible catalytic cycle is proposed and represented in Scheme 3 . First possible pathway (path A) involves formation of self coordinated dimeric ether species 4, which is formed by sulphated Al-MCM-41 catalyzed self condensation of 1. Meanwhile, ether 4 could also be transformed into the carbocation 5 under acidic condition, which was thought to generate 1. The nucleophilic addition of 2 over 5 would result in the generation of vinyl cation 6. Then 6 subsequently hydrates to form the desired product 7 through deprotonation and tautomerization. In order to verify the specified mechanism, species 4 was isolated from the reaction mixture and conformed by GCMS. Further we carried out controlled reaction of 4 with 2 under standard conditions and it was observed that this reaction provides 7 in significant yields. Construction of desired product 9 could be elucidated by direct coupling of 3 with reactive intermediate 5 which leads to formation of carbocation species 8. After this, formation of 9 can be followed by de-protonation of 8. In another practical pathway (path B) initially 1 is activated by sulphated Al-MCM-41 which may result in formation of carbocation intermediate 5 directly. 5 may in sequence react with 2 or 3 to form desired products 7 and 9 respectively. In both the pathways, the reaction mechanism would be the same after intermediate 5 upto formation of the products. 6 Conclusions In summary, a simple but highly efficient methodology has been developed following impregnation and co-condensation methods for synthesis of sulphate modified Al-MCM-41 catalysts. The high surface area with active silanol groups and suitable pore size and pore volume of Al-MCM-41 are the key factors for even dispersion of the active components. Due to vast scope for combination of simple and readily available substrates with their wide functional groups tolerance, this developed chemistry really improves the scope for obtaining a variety of products. The principal advantage of the present protocol lies in the fact that sulfated Al-MCM-41 is effective under mild conditions to provide high yield of products with better selectivity, a simple work-up process and good recyclability for up to six successive runs with high activity. The developed CC coupling protocol is simple, easy to handle and could be a supplement for the synthesis of a wide variety of organic intermediates. 6.1 A standard experimental process for the addition of benzhydrol to phenylacetylene In a typical reaction mixture, Sulphated Al-MCM-41 (40 wt%) (50 mg) in DCE (2 mL), 1a (1 mmol), 2a (1.2 mmol) was added. The reaction solution was heat and stirred at 70 °C for 8 h and by using GC/TLC the progress of the reaction was examined. At the end of the reaction, mixture was cooled to room temperature then the product was extracted in the ethyl acetate and the catalyst was filtered off using a pump. The ethyl acetate layer was dried over anhydrous Na2SO4, evaporated under reduced pressure. The residue obtained was purified by column chromatography [silica gel, 60–120 mesh; PE:EA] to give the desired product 3aa in 87% yield. The product analysis was carried out by GC–MS, 1H NMR, 13C NMR spectroscopic techniques. The purity of the product was checked by GC–MS analysis. After extraction, the filtered catalyst was washed with water and acetone then dried in oven for an hour at 100 °C at 1 atm pressure and then charged with 1a and 2a directly for successive runs. coredata.dc:description: A series of sulphate modified Al-MCM-41 acid catalysts are synthesized following impregnation and co-condensation methods The physico-chemical characterizations of all the samples are done by XRD, FT-IR, TGA/DTA, TPD, N2 adsorption and desorption study, SEM, HRTEM and EDAX etc. The structural advantages of Al-MCM-41 such as large specific surface area, wide pore size and pore volume and Bronsted and Lewis acid sites favor the coupling reaction. The catalysts endorsed the direct addition of alcohols to alkynes as well as their coupling with styrenes. The various combinations of alcohols with alkynes and styrenes are compatible with diverse functional groups to synthesize a substituted aryl ketones, as well as olefins with good to excellent yields. Additionally, the approach is advantageous in terms using alcohols, discounting the pre-functionalization and generation of waste by-products. Used precursors, alkynes and styrenes, are valuable since they are stable and found in many biologically active compounds. This current research work provides supplements to CC bond formation methodologies as a single step with atom economy and recyclable approach under mild and environmentally benign conditions.
coredata.dc:title: Sulphated Al-MCM-41: A simple, efficient and recyclable catalyst for synthesis of substituted aryl ketones/olefins via alcohols addition to alkynes and coupling with styrenes
